awd_titl_txt: CAREER:  The Geography of Tame Ordered Structures
awd_abstract_narration:
At the heart of logic and model theory lies the observation that within mathematics there are certain objects that have to be considered tame, and others that have to be considered wild. Many celebrated results in logic from the first half of the 20th century concerned the existence of objects considered wild. Gödel's proof of the undecidability of arithmetic established that this structure is complicated (or wild) from a logical viewpoint. Such results are negative in spirit as they point to the limitations of mathematical reasoning. However, in the second half of the last century the focus changed. Model theorists found a vast number of tame mathematical structures that exhibit no such wildness, and for often very different reasons are amenable to model-theoretic methods. This program of identifying and analyzing tame classes of structures whose model theory can be understood came to be known as the geography of tame mathematics, and in its various forms has dominated model theory throughout the last thirty years. Although arising as a program of foundational importance, it has led to striking applications of model theory to other areas of mathematics, most recently to the André-Oort conjecture in number theory. Since this program is to explore areas of tame mathematics, these connections are not coincidental at all. The development of such interactions has proven again and again to have far reaching applications outside of logic that could not have been envisioned beforehand.

This project continues this line of research in the setting of expansions of the real line. It aims to settle important open questions within model theory, but also naturally develops new connections between model theory and other areas in logic such as neostability and descriptive set theory, and outside of logic such as geometric measure theory and geometric group theory. The investigator will lead a large scale investigation of dividing lines between tame and wild behavior arising in the study of the geometry of definable sets in ordered structures. Building on early advances, the investigator will determine far reaching consequences of various logical tameness conditions on the topological and metric tameness of definable sets. Furthermore, the project comprises new challenges in the classification of classes of structures considered tame. The educational component of this CAREER grant ties together the investigator's research with his teaching and outreach efforts. This project involves undergraduate and graduate students and young researchers in the investigator's research program, strengthens the ties between model theory and other branches of mathematics, and continues the investigator's outreach efforts in the Urbana-Champaign area.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Below, the PI refers to Philipp Hieronymi.

Intellectual merit.

Results of this project are significant advances in the model theory of ordered structures, in particular - but not only - in the study of expansions of the real line. These fundamental findings have the potential to shape future directions of this research area and connected areas in theoretical computer science. During the five years of this project, the PI with his collaborators  and students has either solved or made substantial progress towards solving many of the research questions outlined in the original proposal. The classification of expansions of the real field by discrete subgroups of the general linear group, decidability results for Sturmian words and the development of Pecan, and the undecidability of the theory of Presburger arithmetic expanded by predicates for the powers of 2 and 3 are particularly noteworthy results.The latter solves a problem that had been open for at least 30 years. Furthermore, advances were made in better understanding geometric tameness in expansions of the real line; in particular that such  structures can be separated into four distinct classes such that in each class definable continuous functions behave rather differently.

The undecidability of the theory of the previously mentioned expansion of Presburger arithmetic has the potential to impact certain parts of theoretical computer science as it generalizes the famous Cobham-Semenov theorem. Indeed, the undecidability result implies the following: Given two subsets of some Cartesian power of the natural numbers such that both are not Presburger-definable, but one is 2- and the other one is 3-recognizable, then they are not only distinct (as follows from Cobham-Semenov), but together computationally intractable over Presburger arithmetic.


Broader impact.

Organize outreach events at University of Illinois.
This grant supported two large outreach events featuring activities designed for K-12 students. The first such event supported by this grant was part of the Four Color Fest in 2017, marking the 40th anniversary of the proof of the Four Color Theorem. Melinda Lanius, then a graduate student, prepared a beautiful activity book, playfully explaining the sophisticated mathematics behind the solution of the Four Color problem. The second large outreach event celebrated Julia Robinson's 100th birthday in 2022 with an estimated attendance of several hundred members of the Urbana-Champaign community.

Include undergraduates in research projects.
Throughout this project, the PI ran 10 semester-long research projects for over twenty undergraduate students through the Illinois Geometry Lab. Two research publications with undergraduate co-authors resulted from these projects.
The PI recruited students from the Merit program at Illinois that targets students with high potential who are members of groups that tend to be underrepresented in the STEM areas. Five of the undergraduate participants are former participants of the Merit program at Illinois.

Prepare graduate students for future careers. Throughout this project, the PI has been supervising nine graduate students (including Master students). Three of these graduate students have already defended their PhD theses, and two of them got postdoctoral positions at research universities. Thanks to the support of this grant, three of the PhD students were able to spend significant time at long-term research programs in Paris and Toronto.


Last Modified: 10/21/2022
Modified by: Timur Oikhberg
